user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleLoad_Static:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleLoad_Static(const char *ModuleName)
{
    int32                      return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym   = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE;

    while (StaticSym != NULL)
    {
        if (StaticSym->Name == NULL)
        {
            /* end of list  */
            break;
        }
        if (StaticSym->Module != NULL && strcmp(StaticSym->Module, ModuleName) == 0)
        {
            /* found matching module name */
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }

        ++StaticSym;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleLoad_Static:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef const struct
{
    const char *Name;
    void (*Address)(void);
    const char *Module;
} OS_static_symbol_record_t
...
#define OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE OS_STATIC_SYMBOL_TABLE
...
#define OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND (-17)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No language/compiler extensions are used in the provided code fragments. The function body only uses standard C constructs: typedef aliases (int32 -> int32_t), pointer iteration (++StaticSym), NULL checks, strcmp (standard library), function-pointer member in the struct, and macro aliases (#define OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE OS_STATIC_SYMBOL_TABLE). The typedef of a const-qualified struct (typedef const struct { ... } OS_static_symbol_record_t) is legal standard C (not a compiler extension). There are no visible compiler-specific attributes, builtin functions, asm statements, pragmas, or other documented extensions in the supplied code. Note: the macro OS_STATIC_SYMBOL_TABLE (referenced via OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE) is not shown; if that macro or the symbol it expands to uses a compiler-specific extension, that expansion would need to be inspected — but based on the code provided, no extensions are present.
